alert.note: Alert for Wells (Indiana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS NorthernIndiana (Northern Indiana and Northeastern Ohio)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 20 at 9:14PM EST until February 22 at 10:00AM EST by NWS NorthernIndiana
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Indiana... Wabash River near Linn Grove affecting Adams and Wells Counties. Wabash River near Bluffton IN affecting Wells County. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Ohio... Indiana... Saint Joseph River Ohio below Montpelier affecting Williams County. Tippecanoe River above Winamac affecting Pulaski, White and Carroll Counties. Tippecanoe River near Ora affecting Pulaski, Marshall, Fulton IN, Starke and Kosciusko Counties. Saint Joseph River Ohio near Newville affecting Allen IN, De Kalb and Defiance Counties. Tiffin River at Stryker affecting Fulton OH, Williams and Defiance Counties. North Branch Elkhart River at Cosperville affecting Noble County. .Runoff from melting snow and additional rainfall early this week will result in a slowing of the recession of river levels. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TUESDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Wabash River near Bluffton IN. * WHEN...Until late Tuesday morning. * IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, River Road at Bluffton begins to flood. Flood waters isolate the amphitheater at Kehoe Park in Bluffton. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 PM EST Sunday the stage was 10.7 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:45 PM EST Sunday was 10.8 feet. - Forecast...The river will fall below flood stage late tomorrow morning to 6.9 feet and then begin rising Tuesday evening. It will then rise again to 7.3 feet early Wednesday afternoon. It will fall to 7.2 feet and then begin rising Wednesday evening. It will then rise again to 7.3 feet Thursday evening. It will fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Detailed river forecasts and additional information can be found at www.weather.gov/iwx under Rivers and Lakes. This statement will be updated within the next 12 to 24 hours.
